questions.question: In the transition from Practitioner to CEO (Lesson 1), what is the primary shift required in time allocation?
options: Moving from 80% clinical work to 80% strategic growth and 'on-the-business' tasks
Increasing clinical hours to generate more immediate cash flow for hiring
Focusing exclusively on social media marketing while outsourcing all clinical decisions
Eliminating all client contact immediately to focus on venture capital acquisition
questions.explanation: The CEO mindset requires shifting from working 'in' the business (clinical delivery) to working 'on' the business (strategy, systems, and leadership), typically aiming for an 80/20 split in favor of growth.

questions.question: When scaling the D.I.G.E.S.T. Method™ through group coaching (Lesson 2), which format offers the highest level of leverage for the expert?
options: One-on-one intensive consulting
A hybrid model with pre-recorded curriculum and weekly group Q&A sessions
Customized meal planning for every individual in a 50-person group
Daily private text support for all group members
questions.explanation: A hybrid model leverages the expert's time by using pre-recorded content for education while reserving live time for high-impact group interactions, allowing for a larger client base without a linear increase in hours.

questions.question: In a Digital Product Ecosystem (Lesson 3), what is the strategic role of a 'Tripwire' product?
options: A high-ticket $5,000 certification for other professionals
A free lead magnet used only for email collection
A low-priced, high-value offer (e.g., $27-$47) designed to convert a lead into a customer
A software tool used to track gut microbiome diversity
questions.explanation: A Tripwire is a low-friction purchase that shifts the relationship from 'subscriber' to 'customer,' covering ad costs and identifying serious buyers within the ecosystem.

questions.question: When building a multi-disciplinary clinical team (Lesson 4), which role is typically the first 'clinical' hire to free up the founder's time?
options: A Chief Financial Officer (CFO)
A Junior Practitioner or Registered Dietitian to handle initial assessments
A full-time Ph.D. Researcher for lab development
A receptionist with no medical background
questions.explanation: Hiring a Junior Practitioner or RD allows the founder to delegate the delivery of the D.I.G.E.S.T. Method™ protocols, which is essential for clinical scaling.

questions.question: What is a primary advantage of 'White-Labeling' supplements for a gut health expert (Lesson 5)?
options: It requires the expert to build their own manufacturing facility
It allows the expert to build brand equity and higher margins on products they already recommend
It eliminates the need for any clinical liability insurance
It guarantees that the supplements will be sold in major retail pharmacies
questions.explanation: White-labeling allows practitioners to put their brand on high-quality formulas, increasing profit margins and reinforcing brand authority with every bottle the client uses.

questions.question: According to Lesson 6 on Authority Positioning, what is the 'Halo Effect' in PR?
options: The light used in professional video production
A psychological bias where being featured in major media (like Forbes) transfers perceived credibility to the expert's entire brand
The circular diagram used to explain the D.I.G.E.S.T. Method™
A marketing tactic involving religious influencers
questions.explanation: The Halo Effect occurs when the prestige of a media outlet or high-level partnership 'rubs off' on the practitioner, making their expertise unquestioned by potential clients.

questions.question: In Lesson 7, which 'Tech Stack' component is critical for managing the lifecycle of thousands of gut health leads?
options: A basic spreadsheet (Excel)
A Customer Relationship Management (CRM) system with automation
A personal Instagram account
A physical filing cabinet for lab results
questions.explanation: An automated CRM is essential for enterprise scaling to track leads, automate follow-ups, and ensure no potential client falls through the cracks.

questions.question: When preparing for an 'Exit Strategy' (Lesson 8), what makes a gut health business most attractive to an acquirer?
options: The business being 100% dependent on the founder's personal charisma
A large number of one-time clients who never return
Standardized Operating Procedures (SOPs) and recurring revenue models that function without the founder
High amounts of personal debt used to fund marketing
questions.explanation: Acquirers look for 'transferable value.' A business that relies on systems (SOPs) and has predictable recurring revenue is an asset; a business that relies solely on the founder is a job.

questions.question: In the context of scaling, what does the 'E' in the D.I.G.E.S.T. Method™ focus on when applied to operations?
options: Eating more fiber
Eliminating inefficiencies and low-ROI tasks through automation or delegation
Evaluating every single client in a 2-hour 1-on-1 session
Expanding the office space to include a gym
questions.explanation: While 'E' stands for Eliminate in the clinical protocol, in a scaling context, it refers to eliminating operational 'waste'—tasks that do not contribute to growth or can be handled by technology.

questions.question: A gut health clinic sees a 40% increase in revenue after implementing a 'Supplement Subscription' model. This is an example of which scaling principle?
options: Authority Positioning
Building Recurring Revenue Assets
Multi-disciplinary Hiring
White-Labeling Manufacturing
questions.explanation: Subscription models create 'predictable recurring revenue,' which stabilizes cash flow and significantly increases the valuation of the business as a long-term asset.
